solution_line_template: She bought {shorts_count} shorts at ${shorts_price} each so {shorts_count}*{shorts_price}=$<<{shorts_count}*{shorts_price}={shorts_total}>>{shorts_total}
She bought {shoes_count} pair of shoes at ${shoes_price} each so {shoes_count}*{shoes_price}=$<<{shoes_count}*{shoes_price}={shoes_total}>>{shoes_total}
The shorts and shoes cost her {shorts_total}+{shoes_total} = $<<{shorts_total}+{shoes_total}={shorts_and_shoes_total}>>{shorts_and_shoes_total}

We know she spent {total_spent} total and the shorts and shoes cost ${shorts_and_shoes_total} which left a difference of {total_spent}-{shorts_and_shoes_total} = $<<{total_spent}-{shorts_and_shoes_total}={difference}>>{difference}
She bought {tops_count} tops for a total of ${difference} so {difference}/{tops_count} = $5
